We have suffered a lot here in DC over the last few years. Not only have we been stuck in a rat-hole of a stadium (literally), but our team has been impotent on offense and inept on defense. Pontius understates the problems of giving up leads - we gave up tying (or losing) goals in the final minutes of multiple games over the last few years. It's been a real trial.

But this year's team is a revelation. Led by DeRo (getting old but still hanging in), Pontius, Santos, etc., we're getting some really pleasant play up front. And the defense has been solid enough. (After the Olympic qualifying debacle, Bill Hamid has started to regain the form that made him one of our few bright spots over the last few years.) Can we keep it up? I dunno, but I'm pretty happy right now.

One major sticking point is the future stadium for the team. Progress always seems to be right around the corner, but we're still mucking around in RFK. Now, I love it when the stands bounce, but we haven't been able to draw good crowds the last few years. Good core crowds (who make the stands bounce), but not the casual fans. Could be a result of the quality of play, but now that we're getting more attention, we'll see whether we can get a good crowd as a first place team this weekend.

As for Pontius, the man is opportunistic and really makes a difference when he's out there for DCU. But not sure if he's cut out for international play. (Prove me wrong, Chris!!)

And regardless, no matter what, Vamos United!!!

@Patrick: Condolences for you, a genuine supporter. I've got to add to your underachiever list, and in shocking fashion, Lahm as well.

The back line was the real trouble against Italy. Once Balotelli cashed those two chances, it was only poor execution by Italy that prevented a five goal blowout. Marchisio (twice) DiNatale and Balzaretti all had better chances to score in the second half than the Germans did from open play almost the whole game.
Germany can be a kiler side on the counter attack, as the England and Argentina matches in the 2010 WC amply showed. But to win tournaments, they are going to have to conjure wins with dominant possession against good teams (which means that Greece doesn't count).
Still work to do, but with lots of young talent. It wil be interesting to see the 2014 WC squad.

In response to MWW, Wigley et al. account for an aggressive decrease in SO2, over an 80% reduction by 2060. In addition, their climate response of SO2 is very conservative; more detailed calculations of climate responses of sulfate, such as those in the Streets et al. article and others suggest a stronger impact than used in that study, so even lower SO2 emissions in Wigley would give a similar conclusion with more detailed climate response calculations. Finally, it is not only SOx from coal that causes cooling but also NOx and "cooling" PM. In theory, if all coal emissions were removed, as they should be, coal would warm more. However, that's not occurring today or any time soon in the U.S., China, or anywhere else. The bottom line is that both coal and gas are bad for society and cause mortality and global warming. Coal kills more but so does natural gas. Gas warms more, but so does coal. The danger of gas is that it will bring about a faster tipping point in the Arctic, Both coal and gas need to be eliminated immediately to address global warming, air pollution mortality, and energy and economic stability. Neither are justified with the clean alternatives currently and abundantly available.

Kurt, your argument is interesting. First off, carbon dioxide becomes toxic in air at varying concentrations and at varying exposure time frames. Case in point: the principal plot of the movie "Apollo 13".

So. If I'm not mistaken, your argument is not about the toxic effects of carbon dioxide on humans, which it does have at higher concentrations. Instead your argument is that carbon dioxide at normal atmospheric concentrations of say 385 to 400 ppm (and climbing) is not toxic to humans so therefore is not hazardous and should not be regulated.

However, I believe the EPA is saying that carbon dioxide and other constituents are green house gases (GHGs). GHGs effect the climate by trapping heat from the sun. If GHGs increase too much, more heat is trapped - things get bad. In order to minimize an increase in concentration of GHGs, human sources have to be regulated.

Is your argument essentially saying the third paragraph or EPA's position is wrong?

If this discussion were a meeting, I would have walked out or been kicked out. It has happened. Both sides have their respective hysteria, which is understandable and comes with the territory for energy and environment concerns.

I think the argument for or against fracking has to be divided in two: (1) fracking with respect to groundwater and (2) fracking with respect to an energy source. This leaves out economic development and climate change. Granted two huge issues. So for me to get on board with the pro fracking side the industry or someone out there in internet-land needs to convince me that fracking in shallow shale will not impact ground water or at a minimum, convince me there is a remedy upon impact. And the cost is not borne on the State or Federal government.

So let's assumed all my concerns with groundwater impact have been laid to rest, I'll need to be convinced that it is a feasible energy alternative. My opinion is... I guess so (presently). However, there should be a set aside or financial trust for research, development and commercialization of truly safe alternative energy sources (what ever they may be). Someone down thread suggested something like this so props to him/her.

Now the issues of economic development and global warming or climate change. At this point it's almost silly until all/most are convinced carbon dioxide, methane, et al do contribute to climate change. My intuition is yes they do. This is way complicated.

Yes, fracking for NG came on line at industrial scales in 1947-49 Halliburton was the first company to use hydraulic fracturing to extract natural gas at an industrial magnitude.

But that early iteration is very different in important ways to what is used in contemporary fracking operations =>Drilling operations could not use the same pressures or magnitudes as today; they could only extract natural gas present in loose geological formations.

The statement" "Peak pressures will vary significantly by well and by age," is then perhaps a bit of an understatement in evaluating what a retired well and its integrity means for aquifer safety.

Seems like extrapolating on wells drilled and/or cased in the latter half of the 20th century won't be very helpful in understanding the very different ones in place (or soon to be), such as pressure, or other questions of potential, ongoing contamination from leaks and broken seals.

Montgomery, et al. (December 2010). “Hydraulic Fracturing: History of an Enduring Technology”. Journal of Petroleum Technology (Society of Petroleum Engineers) 62 (12): 26–32.
